pageData.text: Soil properties vary from layer to layer in a natural body of soil. These variations in properties reflect soil formation conditions and hence can be used to (a) understand how soils form and (b) classify soils. Important properties that vary among different soil types as well as soil layers are mineral composition, <button class='glossary-text'>color</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>texture</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>stickiness</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>plasticity</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>effervescence</button>. In this investigation, students analyze example minerals commonly found in soils as well as properties of soil layers.

pageData.text: Many urban areas are currently grappling with high levels of air pollution, improper stormwater management leading to flooding, and increased temperatures due to absorptive materials like asphalt. To mitigate these problems, many cities are trying to incorporate more green infrastructure. As the name implies, green infrastructure relies on natural ecosystem services to mitigate these harms; it also includes green spaces for water retention and flood prevention, and areas of native plants to promote biodiversity. However, when trying to expand their green spaces, cities often face a new challenge - a lack of usable soil. In many urban areas, the soil has been depleted of nutrients, compacted, paved over, or polluted. Soil must either be shipped in from elsewhere, which is costly and can harm the communities from which it is taken, or a new solution must be found. Recently, some scientists have started to experiment with constructed soils or “technosoils”1. These soils can be made from biological and chemical waste, then combined with microorganisms and appropriate other organisms to make soil with specific characteristics. The technology and infrastructure to develop these soils is still being developed but could help urban areas better deal with the consequences of urbanization in the future.

1Deeb, M., Groffman, P. M., Blouin, M., Egendorf, S. P., Vergnes, A., Vasenev, V., Cao, D. L., Walsh, D., Morin, T., & Séré, G. (2020). Using constructed soils for green infrastructure – challenges and limitations. SOIL, 6(2), 413–434.
https://doi.org/10.5194/soil-6-413-2020

pageData.desc: A winding street with plant-filled medians on a hill in an urban city.
pageData.altText: A winding street with plant-filled medians on a hill in an urban city.

pageData.subTitle: Complexity and Heterogeneity of Soil
pageData.text: Soil is extremely complex as it contains minerals, dead , organisms, air, and water—all interacting with each other through various processes. The concentrations of these components and the processes occurring in soil are not the same throughout but are rather (see Figure 1). As a natural body, the properties of soil vary in three dimensions. Soils will vary across a landscape, due to variations such as slope, , and microclimate. It can also vary in depth, which can be seen in its layering, called . This heterogeneity of soil leads to a great diversity of soil properties and varies greatly depending on the environment in which a soil has developed. This development over is influenced by five , which in turn influence the four that give rise to the particular properties of any given soil.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Soil layers labeling humus, topsoil, subsoil, weathered rock fragments, and bedrock, showing grass and roots, earth texture, and stones.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Soil layers labeling humus, topsoil, subsoil, weathered rock fragments, and bedrock, showing grass and roots, earth texture, and stones.

pageData.subTitle: Soil Formation Factors
pageData.text: Soil properties in any given location are the result of affecting the development of that soil over thousands of years. This development is the result of five interacting environmental factors, called soil formation factors: , and .

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Labeled geological process: weathering (breaking down the material), erosion (movement of sediment), and deposition (dropping sediment in a new location)
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Labeled geological process: weathering (breaking down the material), erosion (movement of sediment), and deposition (dropping sediment in a new location)

pageData.text: Climate affects soil largely through temperature and precipitation, which both affect . Weathering is all changes in rocks and minerals over time, from changes in chemical composition, , to the breaking down of rocks into smaller physical pieces, (see Figure 2). Chemical weathering is generally faster in warmer climates because chemical reactions occur faster at higher temperatures. Chemical weathering is also faster in wetter climates for two main reasons: water is necessary for many chemical weathering reactions and can dissolve solid minerals, increasing their reactivity. Water also contributes to physical weathering in that it can cause minerals to swell and expands when frozen, both of which can break adjacent particles.

affect both physical and . Plant roots can physically push against and break rocks, as can burrowing animals. And for chemical , plants, lichens, fungi, microbial organisms, and others all can play a role during their biological functioning. This activity can have major impacts on the properties and development of a soil since living organisms can be extremely abundant in many ecosystems. One example of how living organisms impact chemical weathering is in plants producing both acids and sugars in their roots. The acids interact with and transform minerals and can dissolve nutrients. The sugars are utilized by microbes, which then release enzymes and other chemicals that break down minerals and . Such interactions can accelerate soil development in highly biodiverse environments. In to their biological activity, dead organic matter plays an important role in soil development as well in the form of and . Detritus is dead organic tissue that hasn’t decomposed yet, and humus is decomposed material that was once part of a living organism.

refers to both and . Topography, specifically where a soil is located relative to landscape features like hills and valleys, primarily influences how much water and sediment the soil may receive. For example, soil at the bottom of a hill receives not only raindrops hitting the soil directly but also water flowing from uphill. Aspect is the compass direction a slope faces, and it influences soil development due to differences in both temperature and water. For example, in the northern hemisphere, south-facing slopes receive more sunlight than north-facing slopes, making them warmer and drier. Generally, this leads to faster weathering on south-facing slopes; however, in dry , warmer temperatures dry out the soil, leading to slower weathering.

<button class='glossary-text'>Parent material</button> is the type of rock, sediment, or organically derived material from which a soil develops. Soil can form from solid rock, sediments, or dead plants. When forming from rock, the depth of the soil (depth to which one could dig before hitting bedrock) generally increases with increasing weatherability of the rock. Sediments are unconsolidated (loose) materials as opposed to being one continuous mass like bedrock. Soil develops faster from sediment than solid rock due to its greater surface area, which enables greater chemical weathering opportunities via reactions and biological activity. Lastly, soil can also form from dead plant materials. This usually occurs in wetlands, such as swamps and marshes, where there isn’t enough oxygen for microbes to decompose dead plants. Since they come from living organisms, these soils have over 30% organic matter and are called <button class='glossary-text'>organic soils</button>.

<button class='glossary-text'>Time</button> refers to the number of years elapsed since soil started forming from its parent material. Time can be considered a multiplier of the first three factors since the older a soil is, the longer climate, organisms, and relief have had to weather and act upon the parent material. Generally, as a soil ages, it becomes deeper with more layers and greater acidity (lower pH).

The do not act independently but rather work together (see Figure 3). Understanding these soil formation factors can help predict complex soil properties from more measurable variables, such as . The factors also make soil a window into the past, proving them invaluable to archaeologists, paleontologists, and paleoclimatologists.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Diagram with soil in the center and arrows pointing to, from, and between animals, topography, parent materials, vegetation, and climate to show multiple factors of soil formation
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Diagram with soil in the center and arrows pointing to, from, and between animals, topography, parent materials, vegetation, and climate to show multiple factors of soil formation

pageData.subTitle: Soil Formation Processes and Horizination
pageData.text: Each affects the rate of various processes occurring in soil. These are divided into four main : , , , and . Together, these processes result in , the development of soil layers from homogeneous material (see Figure 4). The processes are defined based on where they move or change materials relative to the soil. Each is applied to a known volume of soil in a known location, called a . Relative to this soil profile, each process can be defined as follows:

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Soil forming factors influence soil formation processes, which in turn cause horizons to develop from an initially homogenous parent material
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Soil forming factors influence soil formation processes, which in turn cause horizons to develop from an initially homogenous parent material

text: Additions are inputs into the soil profile from outside.
Transformations are changes of one type of soil material to another within the soil profile.
Translocations are movements of materials within the soil profile, in any direction.
Losses are outputs of materials from inside the soil profile to outside.

pageData.text: It is this movement within a soil that are main contributors to development (see Figure 5).

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Examples of particle movement within and between soil horizons, including additions, translocations, transformations, and losses
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Examples of particle movement within and between soil horizons, including additions, translocations, transformations, and losses

pageData.subTitle: Master Horizons
pageData.text: A soil is a layer of the soil in which the physical, chemical, and biological characteristics differ from the layers above and/or below (see Figure 6). Not all soils contain every master horizon, but they all have at least two. Below are the master horizon definitions, going from top to bottom:

text: <button class='glossary-text'>O horizons</button>, when present, are found on the surface. They are composed of mainly <button class='glossary-text'>organic matter</button> derived from recently living things, such as leaf litter on a forest floor. These horizons form due to <button class='glossary-text'>additions</button> from living things. This horizon can also be buried.

contain a mixture of mineral and organic particles, and result from the mixing in (i.e., ) of organic matter into mineral layers below. Burrowing organisms like earthworms and ants help with this process. This layer therefore forms due to both additions and translocations. It is often called topsoil.

are zones where select minerals or organic matter have exited the layer in question, causing it to lack that material (E is for exit). These horizons are often gray because colored minerals such as goethite and lepidocrocite have been translocated downward, either winding up in a lower horizon or being lost from the profile entirely. Due to the greater amount of acids produced by trees, these horizons are common in forest soils but rarely occur elsewhere. For example, E horizons are not found in deserts, grasslands, or tundra.
are zones where translocated minerals accumulate from upper horizons. These layers therefore often have higher concentrations of and semi-soluble minerals, such as calcite.

<button class='glossary-text'>C horizons</button> are unconsolidated layers where minimal <button class='glossary-text'>weathering</button> has occurred. These layers therefore strongly resemble the initial <button class='glossary-text'>parent material</button>, although particles may be slightly smaller. They are also porous and loose enough to be dug with a shovel.
<button class='glossary-text'>R horizons</button> are solid, consolidated rock. These cannot be dug with a shovel.

pageData.text: The presence or absence of master horizons are used to classify soils, because these properties influence soil behaviors and ecosystem services, such as the ability to support plant growth.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: Labeled soil horizons: the organic horizon (O) on the surface, the surface horizon (A), the subsoil (B), and the substratum (C).
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Labeled soil horizons: the organic horizon (O) on the surface, the surface horizon (A), the subsoil (B), and the substratum (C).

pageData.question: Given the definition of B horizons, when digging down from A to B horizon, which of the following changes in clay content would you expect to see?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Clay content should increase because B horizons are characterized by accumulations of minerals such as clays.

pageData.question: Given the definition of B horizons, when digging from A to B horizon, which of the following changes in carbonate content would you expect to see?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Carbonate content should increase because B horizons are characterized by accumulation of minerals such as calcite, which contains carbonate.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: B horizons are zones where translocated minerals accumulate from upper horizons. These layers therefore often have higher concentrations of clays and semi-soluble minerals, such as calcite.

img.alt: Figure 6: Labeled soil horizons: the organic horizon (O) on the surface, the surface horizon (A), the subsoil (B), and the substratum (C).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: B horizons are zones where translocated minerals accumulate from upper horizons. These layers therefore often have higher concentrations of clays and semi-soluble minerals, such as calcite.

img.alt: Figure 6: Labeled soil horizons: the organic horizon (O) on the surface, the surface horizon (A), the subsoil (B), and the substratum (C).

pageData.subTitle: Properties Used to Identify Horizons and Classify Soils
pageData.text: Soils are generally classified based on their , and horizons are in turn identified by their physical and chemical properties. The two most important of these are and . Soil texture refers to the relative proportions of particles having different sizes. In order of descending size, these are: (>2 mm), (0.002 to 0.05 mm), and (<0.002 mm). Texture can be measured using the “feel” method or by various laboratory methods. Other important physical properties that tend to increase as clay content increases are and . Stickiness is the degree to which soil particles are attracted to each other, or the amount of resistance they have to being pulled apart. Plasticity is the degree to which soil can be molded or deformed without breaking. Clay content, stickiness, and plasticity tend to be greater in , where clay accumulations are common.

A chemical property that is helpful in identifying soil horizons is Effervescence is the bubbling of soil after acid is added. A list of commonly and occasionally encountered carbonate minerals with their chemical formula and reactions to cold and warm hydrochloric acid (HCl) are listed in Table 1. Test results can vary because of , previous testing, contamination, and specimen purity. When acid is added to soil, it reacts with any minerals containing carbonate (CO32-) and produces carbon dioxide (CO2) bubbles. Minerals containing carbonate include calcite (CaCO3), dolomite [CaMg(CO3)2], and malachite [Cu2(CO3)(OH)2]. The most common acid used to measure effervescence is hydrochloric acid, and it reacts with calcite as follows: CaCO3 + 2HCl ➞ H2CO3 + CaCl2➞CO2 + H2O + CaCl2

Calcite and other carbonate minerals often accumulate in <button class='glossary-text'>B horizons</button>. They affect plant growth and abundance of other organisms by raising the soil pH, because the CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup> anion is a base.

In this investigation, you will measure <button class='glossary-text'>stickiness</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>plasticity</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>effervescence</button> of three provided sets of <button class='glossary-text'>horizons</button> and one collected set of horizons.
Data from King, H. “The 'Acid Test' for Carbonate Minerals and Carbonate Rocks.” Geology News and Information. Geology.com.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before beginning, you will collect and sieve a soil sample. In activity 1, you will meausre the mass of the soil sample and add water to it. Then, you will test the soil for stickiness and photograph the sample. When you have tested all of the samples, you will try to roll the moist soil into a “worm” shape. Then, you will photograph the shape and categorize the soil’s plasticity. When you have tested all of the soils, dry your soils. In Activity 2, you will set up a control of sodium carbonate in a vial. Then, you will add HCl, observe the bubble and record the foam thickness. Next, you will add a soil sample to the vial, add HCL and observe the bubbles and record effervescence. Repeat this for all of the soil samples.

Repeat this for all of the soil samples.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Soil Formation and Horizons investigation manual (item number 580912) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
Wear your safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron for the duration of this investigation.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for the laboratory activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Hydrochloric acid is harmful if swallowed and can cause severe skin burns and eye damage. It is toxic if inhaled. Do not breathe dust/fume/gas/ mist/vapors/spray. Wash thoroughly after handling. Use only outdoors or in a well-ventilated area.
Sodium carbonate can cause eye irritation. Wash skin thoroughly after handling.
pageData.desc: warning symbol
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Never conduct fieldwork on your own, especially in remote areas; always take a responsible partner with you. Prepare and leave a field safety plan, complete with planned survey locations and expected return , with a responsible party. Wear appropriate clothing (long pants and close-toed shoes are usually best), sunblock, and insect repellant if necessary. Be familiar with the potential hazards in your chosen survey areas. Please review the “Field Work” portion of the Laboratory Safety Manual or your school’s specific safety guidelines for more information. Make sure that you are healthy enough to participate in fieldwork. If in doubt, consult your medical practitioner.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities, Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity, Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Minerals are typically inorganic.  What properties do all minerals have?
The presence of what mineral anion is indicated by a reaction with acid (effervescence)?
Which acid is used to measure effervescence?
Microbes in the soil have changed the chemical composition of a soil profile in a certain location. Which of the following soil formation processes has taken place?
Which of the following master soil horizons is most likely to see additions from living organisms?
Stickiness and plasticity of soil tend to be positively correlated with which of the following soil contents?
Which of the following factors is LEAST likely to affect the results of a soil effervescence test?

options.text: the horizon from which the sample was collected
the temperature of the acid added to the soil
previous testing conducted on the soil sample

assestmentData.question: Which of the following items will you need to supply yourself to complete this investigation?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the activities.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work area.
Label 2 containers or zip bags “topsoil” and “subsoil”.
Find a place to dig. Avoid large plants (besides grass) and any areas that have been disturbed by construction (so stay at least 2 ft away from buildings for example).
Take note of your exact location (Longitude and Latitude) using your phone or other GPS-enabled device. Record this information Data Table 1.

Clear off any plant debris or gravel from the surface and start digging into the soil. As you dig, pay attention to how hard it is to push your trowel, shovel, or spoon through the soil, i.e. the penetration resistance. Pay attention to this penetration resistance and the <button class='glossary-text'>color</button> of the soil as you dig; every few centimeters, feel the soil with your hands to see if you notice a change. Take note of the depth at which the properties changed with the ruler.

Collect about 1 cup of soil from the top down to the point where the soil started to change color and , and place it in a container or plastic storage bag labeled “topsoil.” Typically the top soil is between 5 – 8 cm deep, but can be up to 0.5 - 1 m in some locations.

Then collect soil from below the level where the soil first changed color and texture, about 2-3 inches (or until the soil changes color and texture again). Store this soil in a container or bag labeled “subsoil.” Save about 1 cup of soil. Record the depths from which you collected the topsoil and subsoil in Data Table 1.
Note: You may collect more soil to use in future investigations.
Remove large (>2 mm) particles (such as rocks, roots, or twigs) and break up any large clumps. Clumps may contain extra <button class='glossary-text'>clay.</button>

text: You may need to spread the soil out flat to find most of the large particles. A tweezer or chopsticks may help with this step.

If your soil has a substantial amount (>10% or so) of large particles (>2 mm), it will be faster to sieve it with a colander or a sieve (Figure 7). Do not remove aggregates or clumps; crumble as many as possible and pass them through the sieve/colander. These frequently contain extra clay and removing them biases the results.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: a metal colander with handles filled with soil containing excess fragments and a metal bowl filled with a smaller amount of soil that has been strained
pageData.altText: Figure 7: a metal colander with handles filled with soil containing excess fragments and a metal bowl filled with a smaller amount of soil that has been strained

pageData.text: Mix each collected soil sample thoroughly until the soil is about the same throughout. You can do this with your hands or with a spoon.

If you are unsure if a public location is appropriate to collect a sample from, contact your local Parks and Recreation, Fish and Wildlife, State Park, Bureau of Land Management, or National Forest Department.

You will prepare mixed soil samples to mimic <button class='glossary-text'>horizons</button>. Obtain two resealable plastic bags. Label one bag “<button class='glossary-text'>A horizon</button>” and the other “<button class='glossary-text'>B horizon</button>.”
Using the digital scale and weigh boat, measure approximately 4.5 g of Sample X and put in the bag labeled Into the “A horizon.”
Measure approximately 1.0 g of Sample X and put in the bag labeled “A horizon.”

Soil Sample Y is an inhalation danger when dry. Wear a mask when handling it dry. Once it is wet, it is no longer an inhalation danger. <button class='resource-text'>“How to Use a Digital Scale”</button>
Obtain a new weigh boat and measure approximately 0.8 g of Sample Y and put into the bag labeled the “A horizon.”
Measure 5.5 g Sample Y and put into the bag labeled “B horizon.”
Mix the contents of each bag thoroughly using your hands or a spoon.
In Activity 1, you will moisten the soil samples and categorize each sample’s <button class='glossary-text'>stickiness</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>plasticity</button>.
You will be evaluating each soil sample , Collected Topsoil, Collected Subsoil, and with the field test for of wet soil (see Table 2).
Weigh out approximately 20–30 g of the sand. The sand sample will act as a control.
With the pipette or a spray bottle, slowly add water until all the particles appear wetted.

Note: If your soil is very dry, you may want to start with a few pipettes full or ~3 sprays of water. Once the soil starts to get wet, you can slowly add one drop or one small spray at a time. Be sure to take off your gloves to determine soil stickiness.

text: Most soils are at the proper consistency when plastic and mobile, like moist putty. In the case of sand, you’ll want the soil to reach a consistency like a sandcastle.

If the soil remains in a ball (see Figure 8) when it is gently tossed and caught again, proceed to Step 4. If the soil does not remain in a ball when gently tossed and is still dry, add more water one drop at a <button class='glossary-text'>time</button>.

pageData.desc: Figure 8: A bare hand holding a moist rounded mass of soil.
pageData.altText: Figure 8: A bare hand holding a moist rounded mass of soil.

text: If the soil is too wet, add dry soil to soak up the excess water and repeat Step 2.

If the soil is not too wet or too dry and no amount of adjusting the amount of water or soil makes the soil stay in a ball, its textural classification is “sand.” Try this with the labeled “sand” sample to see what a sand soil feels like. Record the results and observations in Data Table 1.

pageData.text: Coat your thumb and forefinger with moist soil, pushing them together and pulling them apart.
Take a picture of your soil that shows how much the soil appears to stick to your fingers.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Use Table 2 to determine the soil stickiness. Record your results in Data Table 1.

tableData.text: No soil (or practically no soil) sticks to your fingers.
The soil begins to stick to your fingers, but when you pull them apart, the soil does not stretch and the other finger has no soil (or practically no soil) that sticks.
The soil sticks to both the thumb and forefinger and tends to stretch a little and pull apart rather than pulling free from your fingers.
The soil sticks firmly to both thumb and forefinger and stretches when the fingers are opened.

pageData.text: Save your sample; you will use it again in Activity 1, Parts B and C, and Activity 2.
Repeat Steps 2–7 for the other soil samples.
Soil Sample Y is an inhalation danger when dry. Wear a mask when weighing it. Once it is wet, it is no longer an inhalation danger.
pageData.desc: warning symbol
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: You will now use the soil samples in Part B and determine soil <button class='glossary-text'>plasticity</button>.
Use the moist soil samples from Activity 1, Part A.

Note: If the soil will not form a ball, it is not plastic. Coarse grained soils (sand) cannot achieve the plastic state of consistency because soil must contain minerals to become plastic, which coarse soils do not contain.
Roll the ball of moist soil between the palms of your hands until it forms a long, round strip like a wire or “worm” about 6 mm thick and 4 mm long.
Take a picture of your “worm.”
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Use Table 3 to determine the soil plasticity. Record your results in Data Table 1.

tableData.text: Will not form a 6 mm diameter roll or if formed, can't support itself if held on end
6 mm diameter roll supports itself; 4 mm diameter roll does not
4 mm diameter roll supports itself; 2 mm diameter roll does not

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 2–4 for the other soil samples.
You will now use the soil samples in Activity 1 Part C to determine soil <button class='glossary-text'>texture.</button>
Use the moist soil samples from Activity 1, Part B.
Place the ball of soil between thumb and forefinger, gently pushing the soil with your thumb, working it forward into a ribbon.

text: Form a ribbon of uniform thickness and width.

pageData.text: Allow the ribbon to emerge and extend over your forefinger and break from its own weight. Take a picture of the ribbon formation, or lack of ribbon formation. If possible, include your hand in the photo, showing the ribbon before it breaks.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Note: You can put your phone or camera in a plastic bag to protect it from the soil samples.

1. If the soil will not form into a ribbon, it is classified as “Loamy Sand”, and the texture is classified as “Course”. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  2. If the soil will not form a ribbon, feels extremely smooth, and it is not gritty at all, it is classified as “Silt”. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.

text: If the ribbon breaks before it is 1” long, pinch off a small piece and get it excessively wet and rub with your forefinger.

pageData.text:
1. Does the soil feel very gritty?
    1. If yes, the soil is classified as “Sandy Loam”, and the texture is “Moderately Coarse”. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  2. Does the soil feel very smooth?
    1. If yes, the soil is classified as “Silt Loam”, and the texture is “Medium”. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  3. If the soil is neither predominately gritty or smooth, it is classified as “Loam”, and the texture is “Medium”. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.

text: Does the soil make a medium ribbon 1” to 2” long before breaking?

pageData.text:
1. Pinch off a small piece and get it excessively wet and rub with your forefinger.
  2. Does the soil feel very gritty?
    1. If yes, the soil is classified as “Sandy Loam”, and the texture is “Moderately Coarse”. Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  3. Does the soil feel very smooth?
    1. If yes, the soil is classified as “Silty Clay Loam”, and the texture is “Fine.” Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  4. If the soil is neither predominately gritty or smooth, it is classified as “Clay Loam”, and the texture is “Fine.” Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.

text: Does the soil make a strong ribbon 2” or longer before breaking?

pageData.text:
1. Pinch off a small piece and get it excessively wet and rub with your forefinger.
  2. Does the soil feel very gritty?
    1. If yes, the soil is classified as “Sandy Clay”, and the texture is “Moderately Coarse.” Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  3. Does the soil feel very smooth?
    1. If yes, the soil is classified as “Silty Clay”, and the texture is “Fine.” Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
  4. If the soil is neither predominately gritty or smooth, it is classified as “Clay” and the texture is “Fine.” Record the results and observations in Data Table 2.
Use the soil triangle (Figure 9) to determine the approximate percentage of sand, silt, and clay ranges. Record the results in Data Table 2.

pageData.desc: Figure 9: A soil analysis chart displayed as an equilateral triangle, with each angle representing 100% clay, 100% sand, and 100% silt.
pageData.altText: Figure 9: A soil analysis chart displayed as an equilateral triangle, with each angle representing 100% clay, 100% sand, and 100% silt.

pageData.text: Set aside approximately one teaspoon of soil to use in Activity 2.
Repeat Steps 1–5 for each soil sample.
In Activity 2, you will add HCl to your soil samples and observe <button class='glossary-text'>effervescence</button> to understand the soil’s mineral content.

typeBefore.text: Note: Make sure you are wearing gloves, goggles, and your apron before proceeding with the soil test.

pageData.text: Obtain a test tube from the equipment set. Label the test tube “Control.”
Use the digital balance, weigh boat, and spoon to measure 1.5 g of sodium carbonate. Pour it into the test tube labeled “Control.”
Add a few drops of hydrochloric acid (HCl) to the test tube.
Observe the bubbles and foam thickness (see Table 4). Record your observations in Data Table 1.
Obtain four glass vials from the equipment kit. Label each vial “Collected Topsoil”, “Collected Subsoil”, “ ”, and “”
Pour a small amount of Collected topsoil into the corresponding labeled vial—just enough to cover the bottom.
Add a few drops of hydrochloric acid to the soil in the vial.
Note: If the soil sample is not reacting with the HCl, you may need to add a few more drops.
Observe the sample, and use Table 4 to rank the soil effervescence.
*These classes assume soil is dry. Moist soil may produce fewer bubbles.

pageData.desc: How to Use a Digital Scale

pageData.text: Record your ranking and observations in Data Table 1.
Repeat Steps 6–9 for the other soil samples.

text: Wash the equipment with soap and water.
Dispose of used Soil Sample Y in the household garbage. Save untouched sample for future investigations.
All samples exposed to acid should be thrown away in household garbage.
Sanitize the work space, and wash your hands thoroughly.

pageData.title: Thank you
pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

text: Do stickiness and plasticity appear to be correlated with each other? Use your data to support your answer. What might be responsible for this correlation (or lack thereof)?
Excluding sodium carbonate, which sample appeared to contain the most carbonate minerals? Why - what soil property suggests this?

Consider the 5 soil formation factors and interpret the properties of your collected soil. How do the properties of this soil appear to reflect its formation conditions? You may combine data from this investigation with any previous investigations to support your answer.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Soil layers labeling humus, topsoil, subsoil, weathered rock fragments, and bedrock, showing grass and roots, earth texture, and stones.
Figure 2: Labeled geological process: weathering (breaking down the material), erosion (movement of sediment), and deposition (dropping sediment in a new location)
Figure 3: Diagram with soil in the center and arrows pointing to, from, and between animals, topography, parent materials, vegetation, and climate to show multiple factors of soil formation
Figure 4: Soil forming factors influence soil formation processes, which in turn cause horizons to develop from an initially homogenous parent material
Figure 5: Examples of particle movement within and between soil horizons, including additions, translocations, transformations, and losses
Figure 6: Labeled soil horizons: the organic horizon (O) on the surface, the surface horizon (A), the subsoil (B), and the substratum (C).

pageData.content: Table 1. Acid reactions of carbonate minerals
pageData.title: Table 1.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before beginning, you will collect and sieve a soil sample. In activity 1, you will meausre the mass of the soil sample and add water to it. Then, you will test the soil for stickiness and photograph the sample. When you have tested all of the samples, you will try to roll the moist soil into a “worm” shape. Then, you will photograph the shape and categorize the soil’s plasticity. When you have tested all of the soils, dry your soils. In Activity 2, you will set up a control of sodium carbonate in a vial. Then, you will add HCl, observe the bubble and record the foam thickness. Next, you will add a soil sample to the vial, add HCL and observe the bubbles and record effervescence. Repeat this for all of the soil samples.

tableData.text: No soil (or practically no soil) sticks to your fingers.
The soil begins to stick to your fingers, but when you pull them apart, the soil does not stretch and the other finger has no soil (or practically no soil) that sticks.
The soil sticks to both the thumb and forefinger and tends to stretch a little and pull apart rather than pulling free from your fingers.
The soil sticks firmly to both thumb and forefinger and stretches when the fingers are opened.
Will not form a 6 mm diameter roll or if formed, can't support itself if held on end
6 mm diameter roll supports itself; 4 mm diameter roll does not
4 mm diameter roll supports itself; 2 mm diameter roll does not

pageData.content: How to Use a Digital Scale

data.title: A horizon
data.content: The second horizon from the surface; it contains some organic matter in addition to a mixture of minerals

data.title: Addition
data.content: An input into the soil profile from outside; one of four soil formation processes

data.title: Aspect
data.content: The compass direction a slope faces

data.title: B horizon
data.content: The third horizon from the surface; soil in this region has undergone some degree of weathering and is composed almost entirely of mineral material

data.title: C horizon
data.content: The fourth horizon from the surface; it is generally composed of weathered rock fragments and material from the layers above it

data.title: Chemical weathering
data.content: Changes in rocks and minerals due to changes in chemical composition

data.title: Clay
data.content: Particles that are less than 0.002 mm in size

data.title: Climate
data.content: The prevailing weather pattern over a longer period (decades or centuries); one of five soil formation factors

data.title: Color
data.content: The aspect of any object that may be described in terms of hue, lightness, and saturation

data.title: Detritus
data.content: Dead organic tissue that has not decomposed

data.title: E horizon
data.content: A zone where select minerals or organic matter have exited the layer in question, causing it to lack that material

data.title: Effervescence
data.content: The bubbling of soil after acid is added

data.title: Heterogeneous
data.content: Non-uniform composition

data.title: Horizination
data.content: The development of soil layers from homogenous material

data.title: Horizon
data.content: A layer parallel to the soil surface whose physical, chemical, and biological characteristics differ from the layers above and beneath

data.title: Humus
data.content: Decomposed material that was once part of a living organism

data.title: Living organisms
data.content: Organisms that respond to stimuli, grow, reproduce, and maintain homeostasis; one of five soil formation factors

data.title: Loss
data.content: An output of material from inside the soil profile to outside; one of four soil formation processes

data.title: O horizon
data.content: The uppermost horizon; the most nutrient-rich part of the soil profile mainly because of its abundance in organic matter

data.title: Organic matter
data.content: Dead and decomposing organism tissues along with living microorganisms

data.title: Organic soil
data.content: Soil that has over 30% organic matter

data.title: Parental material
data.content: The type of rock, sediment, or organically derived material from which a soil develops; one of five soil formation factors

data.title: Physical weathering
data.content: Changes in rocks and minerals due to the breaking down of material into smaller pieces

data.title: Plasticity
data.content: The degree to which soil can be molded or deformed without breaking

data.title: R horizon
data.content: The deepest horizon; it consists of unaltered bedrock material

data.title: Relief
data.content: Difference in elevation; one of five soil formation factors

data.title: Sand
data.content: Particles ranging from 0.05 to 2 mm in size

data.title: Silt
data.content: Particles ranging from 0.002 to 0.05 mm in size

data.title: Soil formation factor
data.content: One of five environmental factors that influences the development of soil

data.title: Soil formation process
data.content: One of four processes that develops soil horizons

data.title: Soil profile
data.content: The vertical section of soil from the surface layer down to where the soil meets rock

data.title: Stickiness
data.content: The degree to which soil particles are attracted to each other

data.title: Texture
data.content: The proportion of sand-, silt-, and clay-sized particles that make up the mineral fraction of the soil

data.title: Time
data.content: The number of years elapsed since soil started forming from its parent material; one of five soil formation factors

data.title: Topography
data.content: The arrangement of the natural and artificial physical features of an area

data.title: Transformation
data.content: A change from one type of soil material to another within the soil profile; one of four soil formation processes

data.title: Translocation
data.content: The movement of materials within the soil profile in any direction; one of four soil formation processes

data.title: Weathering
data.content: Changes in rocks and minerals over time
